Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Preparing future teachers in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) is critical for the development of a high quality STEM workforce and a STEM literate populace. The Western Regional Noyce Initiative (WRNI) is providing professional development opportunities for Noyce projects located in the western region of the United States through conferences, summer institutes and webinars, enabling Noyce Scholars and Noyce Teachers opportunities to share their experiences and to learn new research-based approaches to teaching. WRNI is helping to increase the number of future STEM leaders in the region's schools; leaders who are prepared to effectively implement the Next Generation Science Standards and/or the Common Core State Standards as more Western Region states fully adopt or include them in their STEM curricula. For Noyce leaders, there are opportunities for a better understanding of the Noyce program evaluation efforts both nationally and locally. Research findings are shared and those campuses that have had years of successful Noyce programs mentor newer campuses, broadening the impact of this initiative.

This two-year initiative provides an opportunity for over 320 Noyce Scholars, Fellows, and Teachers from up to 90 campuses throughout the Western Region to share experiences, learn new teaching strategies and upgrade content knowledge through an annual two-day conference in each year of the two-year project. The conferences are based upon current trends in education (e.g., new standards, recent research in cognitive science, and emphasis on differentiated instruction and English Language Learners) and are based on prior conference evaluations. The conferences expose participants to resources and professional development training in methods that employ proven practices in teacher preparation and induction. Participants are able to collaborate and share experiences, expertise, and skills with their peers and colleagues through presentations, concurrent sessions, person-to-person interactions, and follow-up online networking. The annual conferences also include special sessions for Noyce Leaders focusing on critical elements of project programming and evaluation protocols and outcomes from veteran programs. The science institutes incorporate the Hestenes Modeling approach to teaching with an emphasis on Common Core State Standards and Next Generation Science Standards. Math summer institutes focus on using the Lesson Study approach with an emphasis on Math Common Core Standards. The project emphasizes these emerging standards as important to STEM teaching with the understanding that not all of the states in the Western Region will have adopted the standards during the WRNI project. The summer institutes provide an opportunity for approximately 140 Noyce Scholars and Teachers to attend a professional development program at a Noyce campus in each of two summers (2014 and 2015).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Western Regional Noyce Conference (WRNI) provided multiple professional development and networking opportunities for Noyce Scholars and Principal Investigators associated with Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program from across the Western United States. This region included 14 states: Alaska, Arizona, California, Colorado, Hawaii, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Texas,

Utah, Washington, and Wyoming. Specifically, the project hosted three Western Regional Noyce Conferences, with 384 participants attending in San Francisco November 2014, 381 participants in San Diego November 2015, and 250 participants in Fresno in February 2017. Each of these events ran from Friday evening through Sunday morning and featured keynote speakers, professional development workshops, breakout groups, and networking opportunities. In total, the project involved participants from over 150 Noyce campuses.

 

In addition, the WRNI provided longer-duration intensive summer professional development opportunities over four summers. During Summers 2014-2016, two-week workshops were held at California Polytechnic State University focused around the Modeling Science pedagogical approach promoted by the American Modeling Teachers Association. During the same period, one-week workshops focused on math instruction were offered at CSU Fresno (Summer 2014) and Northern Arizona University (Summer 2015). In total 60 participants attended summer science institutes and 60 participants attended summer math institutes. During Summers 2016-2017, the project also supported a total of 19 Noyce Scholars to participate in nine-week paid summer research opportunities at national labs and other research facilities to develop identity as teacher-researchers as part of their Noyce preparation. These were sponsored by the STEM Teacher and Research (STAR) program www.StarTeacherResearcher.org (STAR website), http://digitalcommons.calpoly.edu/star/ (STAR Posters) headquartered at CSU CalPoly. All three of these professional development opportunities included intentional emphasis on Common Core State Standards (CCSS) and Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS).

 

Intellectual Merit

 

The intellectual merit associated with the Western Regional Noyce Conferences included professional experiences to support teachers who work in high need settings, learning new teaching strategies and upgrading content knowledge through annual two-day conferences. The conferences were structured around current trends in education (e.g., new standards, recent research in cognitive science, and emphasis on differential instruction and English Language Learners and were revised iteratively each year based on feedback provided through conference evaluations. The conferences exposed Noyce participants to resources and professional development training in methods that employ proven practices in teacher preparation and induction. Participants were also able to collaborate and share experiences, expertise, and skills with their peers and colleagues through presentations, concurrent sessions, person-to-person interactions, and follow-up online networking. Overall, the conferences built a network of Noyce Scholars who were better prepared to teach high needs students, who were equipped to adapt instruction to students with different needs, and who had confidence to implement new lessons and teaching strategies. Additionally, the conferences resulted in a network of Noyce leadership that had increased confidence to implement new strategies in their programs and work together to improve local experiences for all Noyce Scholars and assess and publish findings related to the Noyce program and experiences.

 

The intellectual merit of the summer institutes and teacher-research opportunities were centered around a focus on CCSS and NGSS. The science summer institutes utilized the Modeling Science pedagogical approach developed through NSF funding by Arizona State University. The math summer institutes utilized the best practices approach of Lesson Student with an emphasis on Math Common Core Standards. The teacher-researcher opportunity involved both mentored research experience along with structured weekly STEM education workshops emphasizing the translation of the summer research experience into future classroom practice aligned with NGSS and CCSS.

 

Broader Impact

 

The Western Regional Noyce Initiative impacted approximately over 650 aspiring and early-career STEM educators committed to teaching in high need school districts across the Western Region. These participants gained new knowledge on effective STEM teaching, gained more in-depth knowledge of effective student engagement strategies aligned with new science and common core standards, learned about outstanding online resources and learning communities that will help them to achieve at the highest level in the classroom, and interacted with colleagues across a wide region of the United States electronically. The project helped to increase the number of future STEM leaders’ schools prepared to effectively implement the Next Generation Science Standards and/or Common Core State Standards, Noyce leaders developed better understandings of Noyce program evaluation efforts both nationally and locally. Research findings were shared and newer and veteran Noyce leaders interacted to mutually benefit their Noyce programs. This impact helped to sustain Noyce influence at each of the campuses over time and well beyond the lifetime of the award. The indirect impact of WRNI was that possibly up to 120,000 pre-college students annually will receive a STEM education from teachers who are well trained in STEM education.
